title: Ticket #4094: Shared Port forks
description:
It's really quite silly to have shared port fork - on busy schedds, CMS has seen it actually hit our limit of 1,000 child processes and caused blocking.

The protocol server is a single RPC - we send data and wait for an ACK from the server. Instead of forking, we should just register the socket for response from DC and handle from the parent process.
remarks:
2013-Nov-22 13:04:55 by tannenba:
Your suggestion above assumes the shared port will only block waiting for a response from the target daemon. What about if the shared port blocks writing out the request? Processes cannot send an infinite amount of data into a domain socket, right? I think concern of blocking when writing the request was a primary motivation for forking.

2013-Nov-22 13:50:13 by bbockelm:
Hi Todd,

Theoretically, yes, that's an issue for a general service.

Practically, this is not an issue if we assume we are talking to HTCondor daemons. We write 1 byte into the socket, so the HTCondor daemon would have to call accept() 16k times without reading out that first byte.

In testing, you block on somaxconn far before the socket itself.

(FYI - code is at https://github.com/bbockelm/htcondor/tree/shared_port_nonblocking; running through NMI now)

Brian

2014-Feb-08 10:19:13 by bbockelm:
Hi Todd,

Reviewing the last commit - can you please use ClassAd APIs (InsertAttr) instead of compat_classad APIs (Assign) for new code?

Thanks.
